title: James with Acute Onset Chest and Throat Pain Post-Physical Exertion
clinical_history: James is a 43-year-old warehouse supervisor who reported to the clinic with sudden onset of chest and throat pain following an instance of lifting a heavy box overhead 4 days prior. He describes the pain as a pressure and sharp discomfort centrally in the upper chest radiating to his throat, especially when taking deep breaths, speaking loudly, or swallowing solid foods. There is a noted tenderness along the sternocleidomastoid and scalene muscles on palpation, with mild swelling noted over the upper sternum. He denies shortness of breath at rest, diaphoresis, or referred pain in the left arm. He is concerned as his symptoms have not improved and he has trouble turning his head to the left without intensifying throat pain.

nprs.affected_area: Central upper chest (pectoralis major, costochondral junction)

aggrevating_factors: Lifting overhead, forceful coughing, deep inspiration, loud talking, swallowing, rapid head rotation.
picture: [image would illustrate marked areas over upper chest and anterior neck/throat]
easing_factors: Rest, supporting chest with hand when coughing, warm compress over the chest/neck, shallow breathing, soft foods.
past_history: History of recurrent cervical strain secondary to occupation; previous mild costochondritis episode 2 years ago resolved with NSAIDs and rest.
medical_history: No known cardiac or pulmonary disease. Mild hypertension, managed with lifestyle modifications. No significant systemic illnesses.
medications: Occasional acetaminophen for headaches. Currently using ibuprofen 400 mg TID for pain as advised by his PCP since onset.
personal_history: Non-smoker, consumes alcohol socially. Married with two school-aged children. Reports moderate physical activityâ€”walks daily for 30 min. Significant work stress recently due to staff shortages.
imaging: Chest X-ray and ECG performed in ED at symptom onset, both unremarkable. No signs of acute cardiac or pulmonary pathology. No further imaging to date.
